title: 107_hr1137
content: The "Private Sector Research and Development Investment Act of 2001" amends the Internal Revenue Code to extend the research credit and improve the alternative incremental credit. The amendments apply to amounts paid or incurred after the enactment of the Act. The "Private Sector Research and Development Investment Act of 2001" extends the research credit and improves the alternative incremental credit under Section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Taxpayers can elect to determine the credit by taking into account modifications provided in the new subsection. The base amount is computed with a fixed-base percentage equal to 80 percent of the aggregate qualified research expenses. The base period for computing qualified research expenses is the 8-taxable year period preceding the current taxable year, with a minimum gross receipts amount of $1,000,000 for start-up and small taxpayers. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. An election under this subsection applies to the taxable year for which made and all succeeding taxable years unless revoked with the consent of the Secretary. Section 41(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by striking paragraph (4) and redesignating paragraphs (5) and (6) as paragraphs (4) and (5), respectively. MODIFICATIONS TO CREDIT FOR BASIC RESEARCH. The text chunk discusses the elimination of the incremental requirement for the credit allowable with respect to certain payments to qualified organizations for basic research under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. It includes specific amendments to sections and paragraphs within the Code. The text chunk discusses amendments to sections and paragraphs within the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 related to basic research. Amendments include redesignating subparagraphs and changing specific commercial objectives for research. Expansion of Credit to Research Done at Federal Laboratories: Research conducted at federal laboratories is now eligible for tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section allow research conducted at Federal laboratories to be eligible for tax credit under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, effective for taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000. SEC. 5. CREDIT FOR EXPENSES ATTRIBUTABLE TO CERTAIN COLLABORATIVE RESEARCH CONSORTIA. The amendment to section 41 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a 20 percent credit for amounts paid to a qualified research consortium. A qualified research consortium is defined as an organization meeting specific criteria. A research consortium is an organization described in section 501(c)(3) that conducts scientific or engineering research, is not a private foundation, and receives contributions from at least 5 unrelated persons for research purposes. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2000, related to contributions for scientific or engineering research organizations under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. Improvement to credit for small businesses and research partnerships. The Secretary of the Treasury will provide assistance to small and start-up businesses to comply with IRS section 41 and reduce compliance costs. Additionally, the limitation on contract research expenses paid to small businesses, universities, and federal laboratories is repealed. The limitation on contract research expenses paid to small businesses, universities, and federal laboratories is repealed, with a substitution of '100 percent' for '65 percent' for eligible small businesses. Eligible small businesses are defined as those where the taxpayer does not own 50 percent or more of the outstanding stock in the case of a corporation. The definition of a small business for tax purposes includes the annual average number of employees not exceeding 500 in the preceding two years. The definition of a small business for tax purposes includes the annual average number of employees not exceeding 500 in the preceding two years. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include rules for startups, controlled groups, and predecessors regarding the credit for patent filing fees. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a provision for small businesses to receive a 20 percent credit on patent filing fees paid to the United States or foreign governments. This amendment applies to taxable years starting after December 31, 2000.
